prs.title: CCIP-5906 Ignoring fee boosting outcomes
prs.truncated_body:
### Description

Removing FeeBoosting from CCIP 1.5 with minimal impact on the codebase. The entire execution path in the Exec plugin is basically the same; the only difference is logging the difference when a message is underpaid instead of skipping the execution. What is more, there is one more test to the batching logic to confirm costly messages are not ignored but executed.

prs.title: op-supervisor,op-node: Handle non-genesis Interop
prs.truncated_body:
**Description**

The op-node and op-supervisor are taught to handle a non-Genesis Interop activation timestamp properly in managed mode. In essence, the op-supervisor _just does less_ while the op-node does _a bit more_ pre-Interop:

* Before Interop is active, the op-node locally auto-promotes _local_-(un)safe to _cross_(un)safe blocks (as before).
* Only L1 derivation is driven by the op-su

This is a new v2 rewrite of the rewind-locking, to address the following issues:
- rewind locks were mostly only applied to new dead code that was not integrated
- some locks were missing
- composition of multiple per-chain locks was fragile

* Remove wiring of the async-icq module on the app/app.go
* Introduce a v2rc1 upgrade handler for the testnet that removes the module.

commits.message:
chore: Remove async-icq module (#993)

This PR removes the wiring of the async ICQ module. It includes the
following:
* Remove wiring of the async-icq module on the app/app.go
* Introduce a v2rc1 upgrade handler for the testnet that removes the
module.
* Update the v2 upgrade handler to have the option to specify whether to
include the async-icq module or not. For the testnet upgrade, this has
been set to `true`, i.e., include the module, while for the mainnet
upgrade, this option has been set to `false.
* The option was added as the v2 upgrade has already been executed on
the testnet with the module included. In order to have a consistent
sequence of the upgrades for both testnet and mainnet, we need to
maintain the upgrade with the module included.
* An alternative option is to modify the upgrade to v2rc0 for the
testnet and copy its contents in a new v2 upgrade for the mainnet. This
seems to be repeating code and complicating things, so it was not
followed.
* Small updates to resolve a few inconsistencies (e.g., for
`x/tokenfactory` we use `ModuleName` instead of `StoreKey` in the
upgrade).

(cherry picked from commit a34969aaf73e0e051aa445149dfb4bb06255b10d)

# Conflicts:
#	CHANGELOG.md
#	app/include_upgrade_testnet.go
#	app/upgrades/v2/upgrades.go

# StarkNet Direct Minting Implementation

This PR adds a complete L1 Bitcoin Depositor contract that integrates with StarkGate bridge to enable seamless Bitcoin deposits directly to StarkNet L2, following the proven AbstractL1BTCDepositor pattern used across other chains.

### Core Implementation
- **StarkNetBitcoinDepositor.sol** - L1 contract inheriting from AbstractL1BTC

This aligns StarkNet implementation with other L2 integrations (Base, Arbitrum)
and enables future upgradability through OpenZeppelin proxy pattern.

Complete P-002: StarkGate deposit function research

Research findings confirm StarkGate has both deposit() and depositWithMessage()
functions. For simple tBTC transfers without L2 callbacks, using deposit()
is more efficient, saving ~2000 gas per transaction.

Key findings:
- Both functions have identical L1→L2 messaging fees
- Empty message array adds unnecessary overhead
- deposit() is the recommended function for our use case

Test results show all research objectives achieved:
- Interface analysis complete
- Gas measurements documented
- Fee implications analyzed
- Recommendation: Update implementation to use deposit()

to use the more efficient deposit() function instead of depositWithMessage()
with an empty message array.

prs.title: RPC Proxy thenable interference causing setRpc to break
prs.truncated_body:
## Problem
The `setRpc()` function would break immediately when awaited because the RPC object from `@solana/kit` is a Proxy that intercepts ALL property access, including JavaScript's internal check for `.then` during Promise resolution. The Proxy would create an RPC request for method "then" instead of returning `undefined`, causing immediate failure in async/await.

## Changes
- Wrap return
